Tour Spot details
National Martyrs Memorial
Lalbagh Fort
This is one of the major tourist attractions at the outskirts of Dhaka city. This wonderful architectural monument represents the great sacrificing heroes, who sacrificed their lives for the independence of Bangladesh in 1971.
Lalbagh Fort is a historic Mughal esatablishment situated at the old part of Dhaka. This Fort is built with red colored bricks. It is one of the most popular historic places and a great example of art by Mughal Emperor in Bangladesh.
Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujib Safari Park
Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujib Safari Park is a safari park in Gazipur, Bangladesh. This safari park is spread over 3810 acres of Sal Forest which makes it one of the largest safari parks in the world and the largest in Asia. It was inaugurated on October 31, 2013. It is located about 40 km north of Bangladesh capital city Dhaka near the Dhaka to Mymensingh Highway. \n\nThe park is divided into 5 major sections. They are the Core Safari, Safari Kingdom, Biodiversity Park, Extensive Asian Safari Park and Bangabandhu Square.
Aricha Ghat
Aricha Ghat is an important river port in Bangladesh. It is situated in Manikganj District.The port is managed by Bangladesh Inland Water Transport Authority. Daulatdia-Paturia route ferries ply from this port.
Arial Beel
Mawa Ghat
Arial Beel is the third largest wetland in Bangladesh covering an area of 136 sq. km. It Is situated in Srinagar Upazila of Munshiganj District. The beel consists of many small ponds and canals. During the rainy season the plants become livelier and the vast expanse of water with land borders look exotic Though the beel reduces in winter, still remains navigable.The beel abounds in fish and during the dry season the farmers produce corns and vegetables in the dry area. The pumpkin of this beel is famous. You can have a tour of the beel by boats. The beel is just 35 km from Dhaka and can be reached in an hour and a half.
Mawa Ferry Ghat remains the connector of South Bengal to the other part of country via Padma river. Furthermore, the place is famous for traditional Hilsa fish. As a result, this place has become one of the busiest places in the country. People from different places in the country come to Mawa Ghat to roam on the river, taste fresh Hilsa fish and watch the natural beauty of the place. For the people of Dhaka, this place is a very good tourist spot for a day trip.
Panam City
Sonargaon,Lok Shilpa Jadughar
Panam City, also called as the lost city, an archaeological site situated at Sonargaon Upazıla of Narayanganj District. This is the oldest capital of Bengal and the ancient silk road from the Bengal delta to China and Central Asia.
Lok Shilpa Jadughar (Folk Art and Craft Museum) of Sonargaon was established by Bangladeshi painter Joynul Abedin on March 12, 1975. This is prosperous with several unique collections those someone will never find at any other places. There are two Exhibition Galleries inside the museum. Both of them consist of some status showing the local life of Bangladeshi people, for example farming, woman working etc. These are miniature version of old age boats of the country. The baroque decoration and the elaborated painting on the plaster of the building are really eye catching.
Wari Bateshwar
The Wari-Bateshwar in Narsingdi, Bangladesh is the site of an ancient fort city. Based on the artifacts found here the city was active between about 2000 BC (or earlier) to 450 BC. The ruins being unearthed near the old course of the Brahmaputra River are a major archaeological discovery in South Asia, which challenges the earlier notions of early urban civilization in Bengal. \n\nThe discovery of a pit-dwelling is the first of its kind in Bangladesh. The pit-dwelling is a Copper Age or Chalcolithic artefact. Similar pit-dwellings have been found in India and Pakistan which are believed to be 4000 years old. \n\nLater the area was part of the ancient region of Samatata.
Daulatdia Ghat
Paturia and Daulatdia Ferry Ghat, is the main artery of communication between the southern portion of Bangladesh and the Capital city of Dhaka. Here we can watch unloading of vehicles from. The Padma is a major river in Bangladesh. It is the main distributary of the Ganges, flowing generally southeast for 120 kilometres to its confluence with the Meghna River near the Bay of Bengal.
Jamuna Bridge
Madhupur Garh
Bangabandhu Bridge, commonly called the Jamuna Multi-purpose Bridge (Bengali:Jomuna Bohumukhi Setu) and also called the Poongi bridge, is a bridge opened in Bangladesh in June 1998. It connects Bhuapur on the Jamuna Rivers east bank to Sirajganj on its west bank. It was the 11th longest bridge in the world when constructed in 1998 and at present is the 6th longest bridge in South Asia. The Jamuna River, which it spans, is one of the three major rivers of Bangladesh, and is fifth largest in the world in discharge volume.
Madhupur Garh or Madhupur Shalban or Madhupur Jungle is a large forest or raised area located in the center of Bangladesh. Madhupur Garh area extends from the southern part of Jamalpur district in the north to Fatulla thana of Narayanganj Sadar upazila in the south . Tangail and Gazipur districts and most of Dhaka city are included in this average region.The northern part of the average is known as Madhupur average and the southern part as Bhawal average. Madhupur National Park is made up of the average part of Madhupur Upazila in Tangail and Bhawal National Park is made up of some parts of Gazipur. \n\nAfter the Madhupur forest came under the Forest Department in 1972, initiatives were taken to conserve the biodiversity of the forest. According to the Bangladesh Wildlife Conservation Act of 1974, the purpose of conserving biodiversity was declared in 1972. 6438 hectares of this forest was declared as two national parks named Madhupur and Bhawal.
Bangabandhu Mausoleum
The complex is known as the Mausoleum of Father of the Nation Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman or colloquially as Tomb of Bangabandhu. It was established on 15 June 2001 by the then Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina. \n\nBangabondhu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, father of the Nation of Bangladesh, lies in eternal peace at this place with his parents. \n\nEntering from the Patgati-Tungipara Road, the complex opens up to a large, open well-organised space containing, amongst other things, a museum which showcases both popular and rare photographs from Sheikh Mujib\'s life. There\'s also a small library in the museum. The complex also contains a small shop and a large cafeteria for hungry visitors. In a far corner, there\'s a small open stage which signifies the countless number of times Sheikh Mujib stood up and gave powerful, resonating speeches to his fellow Bengalis.
Kantaji Temple
Sitakot Vihara
Shopnopuri Artificial Amusement Park
Kantaji or Kantanagar Temple is an eighteenth century brick built temple, situated at Kantanagar, Dinajpur. About 20 km north of Dinajpur town and about 1.5 km west of Dinajpur-Tetulia highway. This nava-ratna or \'nine spires\' Hindu Temple is the most sought after because of its wonderful terracotta embellishment. The visitors are just spell-bound to see the wall of the temple, every inch of which are plagued with wonderful terracotta.
Sitakot Vihara is an archaeological site located in Nawabganj upazila in Dinajpur district of Bangladesh. The site is locally known as the residence of Sita. Through regular excavations in the years 1968 and 1972-1973, an ancient Buddhist monastery was discovered in the site. The monastery dates from a similar time period to the nearby Somapura Mahavihara and Halud Vihara.
Shopnopuri Artificial Amusement Park is an artificial spot for tourists situated in Dinajpur district of Rangpur division in Bangladesh. There are rides, a zoo, a resthouse, a garden, lakes, central picnic center and countless shopping areas. Other tourist locations include Fish World, \‘Rongdhonu\’ Art Gallery, and \‘Moha Maya Indrojal\’. Fish World offers artificial fishes and various wet animals. The Animal Kingdom is filled with artificial statues of some animals like flamingos, dinosaurs, Pegasus and many more. \‘Rongdhonu\’ Art Gallery has a variety of sculptures and paintings. At \‘Moha Maya Indrojal\’, there is magic. And there are a variety of animals. It is a popular site for picnics.
Tista Barrage
One of the largest barrages in Indian subcontinent. It got 51 switch gates. It controls the water supply of the whole Bangladesh rivers. Besides it\'s a tourist spot, there is a park beside it. Area of beside the bridge is wonderful, blessed with nature.
Tajhat Palace
Tajhat Palace, is a historic palace of Bangladesh, located at Tajhat, Rangpur. The palace was built by Maharaja Kumar Gopal Lal Roy at the beginning of the 20th century. It is believed that from the conspicuous appearance of his Taj or jeweled crown, his estate derived the name of Tajhat. The Palace is situated three km. south-east of the city of Rangpur, on the outskirts of the town.
Srimangal, Tea garden
Madhabkunda Waterfall
Lawachara Rain Forest
Baikka Beel
Srimangal, the tea-capital of Bangladesh is famous for tea garden covered by the green carpet and also called the land of two leaves and a bud. It\'s a soothing landscape of terraced tea gardens, pineapple, rubber and lemon plantations. A good number of luxury resorts and villas have made Srimangal as the best holiday-making destination. Staying few days around tea estates or any resort and exploring nearby villages and forests certainly be enounced complete rejoice of travelling in Srimangal, beauty of the place of leaves and bud.
Madhabkunda waterfall is one of the most beautiful and attractive waterfalls in Bangladesh. The green leafy trees, big bolder of black stones make this waterfall so charming and eyes catching.
To get the taste of a mysterious rain forest, Lawachara is perfect place to visit. The well- conserved forest offers ample opportunities for trekking and jungle walking. There have over 460 different species of birds, mammals and reptiles that live in this forest, such as deer, wild chickens, wild chicken, squirrels, pythons, endangered hoolock gibbons, capped langurs, slow loris, birds, snakes, banana spiders etc.
Baikka Beel, a sanctuary for birds and fish, is located in Srimangal and Moulovibazar. It is a part of Hail Haor. The beel has an area of 1000 hectares and comprises of open water with emergent vegetation and a fringe of native swamp forest. Thousands of birds live here and thousands more migrate. You can watch birds throughout the year. When you enter the wetland area you will be engrossed by the chirping of birds. There is a watch tower at the centre of the beel. The beel has a beautiful view with birds as well as lilies, lotuses and other aquatic plants and flowers. There are 98 species of fish mostly local and 160 species of birds including migratory ones. Experienced people say Baikka Beel is the best place in the country for bird watching. Best place for night stay is Srimangal where there are plenty of hotels and guest houses.
Tanguar Haor
Chhatak
Tanguar Haor is one of the largest natural water reservoirs in the South Asia. Because of its diverse natural and aquatic features, it has been declared as a Ramsar site by IUCN. The site wears different looks at different seasons to attract the tourists. During rainy season, the Haor becomes a sea with strong waves. In winter green fields of miles after miles, hundreds of canals, thousands of migratory birds, fishermen in the ditches are just fabulous for the tourists.
Chhatak is a town in northeastern Bangladesh, on the Surma River in Chhatak Upazila of Sunamganj District in the division of Sylhet. This town is ever green. Here, people of all religions live in peace.
Jaflong
Ratargul Swamp Forest
Haripur Gas Field
Jaflong is a wonderful tourist spot, 56 kilometers away from the Sylhet city. The spot filled with mountains and streams, offers wide varieties of experiences for the visitors. Rollıng rocks, crystal clear water of the Gowain river abound with fish and other aquatic species create a fantastic scenic beauty for nature lovers. The indigenous people khasi live in this region for thousands of years whose colorful lifestyle is enjoyable to anyone.
Ratargul is a freshwater swamp forest located beside Gowain river, Fatehpur union, Gowainghat, Sylhet. This is an evergreen and one of the best freshwater swamp forests in the world. The beauty of this forest is bloomed mainly in the rainy season.
Haripur Gas Field is a natural gas field located in Sylhet area of ​​Bangladesh. Gas was first discovered here in 1955 and the first gas extraction started in 1956. So far a total of 6 gas wells have been drilled here. Oil has also been found in one of them.
